description:
Chelonoidis abingdonii, also known as the Pinta Island tortoise or Abingdon Island tortoise, is an extinct species of Galápagos tortoise that was native to the island of Pinta in the Galápagos archipelago. This species was characterized by its unique dome-shaped carapace and large, elongated neck and head, which were adaptations to the island's environment.

The Pinta Island tortoise was a herbivore, feeding primarily on various plant species found on the island. It played a crucial role in the ecosystem, acting as a seed disperser and contributing to the maintenance of the island's vegetation. Sadly, this species was driven to extinction due to human activities, such as hunting and the introduction of non-native species that competed for resources.

The last known individual of this species, a male named "Lonesome George," was discovered in 1971 and was the focus of conservation efforts to try and save the species. However, despite these efforts, Lonesome George died in 2012, marking the official extinction of the Pinta Island tortoise. The loss of this unique species is a significant blow to the biodiversity of the Galápagos Islands and serves as a sobering reminder of the importance of conservation efforts to protect endangered species.
